linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on oil saturation, porosity, and permeability of three-dimensional model, we determined the most potential well candidates for injection wells—not only producing wells, but also shut-in wells. There are six selected wells which are MJ-122, MJ-127, MJ-74, MJ-125, MJ-116 and MJ-42 TW (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Well Candidate at Mangunjaya Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Candidate at Mangunjaya Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Recording microbe population (Total Plate Count/TPC) in produced water of MJ-125 well is shown in Figure 19

image-wrap.label: Figure 19

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Graph of Microbe Total Population from Produced Water of MJ-125 well during monitoring stage

linkTarget.anchoringText: The dynamics of microbial growth in oil well of MJ-122 during production shown in Figure 20. The overall growth of bacteria increased from 2×103 CFU / mL to 5×106 over the period of 176 days.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: The Graph of Microbe Population and Water Cut during Production Stage on MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Graph of Microbe Population and Water Cut during Production Stage on MJ-122

linkTarget.anchoringText: The graph in Figure 21 shows the dynamics of microbial growth in oil well of MJ-125 during production phase. The overall growth of bacteria increased from 1×105 CFU/mL to 5×108 CFU/mL for 122 days. On the first day of production, 1 December 2015, the number of bacteria was 1×105 CFU/mL and remain constant until 9 December 2015 with the number of bacteria 1×106 CFU/mL. Bacteria in the first 9 days of production is undergoing a lag phase or adaptation phase. The lag phase period of bacteria in MJ-125 was longer than MJ-122, which was assumed to be caused by internal factors such as the activation of the enzyme and/or external factors such as the limited availability of extracellular compounds so that the accumulation of the required extracellular compounds took longer (Madigan et al., 2012). Bacterial growth increased from December 9, 2015 (the ninth day) until December 16, 2015 (the sixteenth), from 1×106 CFU/mL to 3×108 CFU/mL.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: The graph of Microbial Population and Water Cut during Production Stage on MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: The graph of Microbial Population and Water Cut during Production Stage on MJ-125

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the results of GC-MS analysis (Figure 22) of the samples before and after the injection process (1 to 4 months after injection), it shows that there are changes to the high baseline chromatogram. Compared with a sample before production (September 2015), the samples from the 1st month to the 4th month shows a decrease in baseline after a retention time of 20.00. Similarly, production samples of 5th month compared with the 6th month shows a decrease in baseline after a retention time of 20.00. Decrease in baseline indicates a decline in the amounts of hydrocarbons due to the activity of hydrocarbon degradation by bacteria. The establishment of more peak before the retention time of 15:00 also indicates that the degradation occurs to utilize complex hydrocarbon chains to be simpler hydrocarbon chains.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: The comparison of chromatograms of MJ-122’s Oil before injection (Black), after 1 month of production (Red), after 2 months of production (Blue), after 3 months of production (Yellow), after 4 months of production (Green), after 5 months of production (Grey), and after 6 months of production (Orange)

formatted-caption.caption-text: The comparison of chromatograms of MJ-122’s Oil before injection (Black), after 1 month of production (Red), after 2 months of production (Blue), after 3 months of production (Yellow), after 4 months of production (Green), after 5 months of production (Grey), and after 6 months of production (Orange)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The changes in hydrocarbon fraction which occurred in MJ-125 oil illustrated in Figure 23. Based on the results of GC-MS analysis of the samples before and after the injection process, it can be seen that at the pre-injection, the production of the first month and the second month of production has similar chromatogram pattern. The differences in patterns of chromatograms before and after the production of the first and second month were only observed in the changes of height of peaks, where the decline occurred in the height of peaks between samples before and after the injection process. The changes on peak height indirectly correlated to the change on the concentration number of the sample.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: The Analysis Result of GC-MS Chromatogram of MJ-125 Oil during Pre-Production until 4 Months after Production

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Analysis Result of GC-MS Chromatogram of MJ-125 Oil during Pre-Production until 4 Months after Production

linkTarget.anchoringText: This indicated unstable community structure changes after injection of microbial communities. However, the interaction between injected microbes with indigenous microbes was not competitive. It was evidenced by the band results in Figure 24 that show that there are 2 bands which always exist at every point of observation, the band on the samples before production is predicted as indigenous microbes.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Reconstruction of SSCP bands of MJ-122 (above) and MJ-125 (below): (A) pre-production, (B) the 1st day production, (C) the 1st week production, (D) the 2nd week Production, (E) the 3rd week production, (F) the 4th week production, (G) the 8th week production, (H) the 12th week production, (I) the 16th week production,(J) the 20th week production, (K) the 24th week production, (Pre) before production, (30 Dec) the early of 1st month production, (14 Jan) the middle of 1st month production, (29 Jan) the early of 2nd month production, (13 Feb) the middle of 2nd month production, (25 Feb) the early of 3rd month production, (7) a positive control.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Reconstruction of SSCP bands of MJ-122 (above) and MJ-125 (below): (A) pre-production, (B) the 1st day production, (C) the 1st week production, (D) the 2nd week Production, (E) the 3rd week production, (F) the 4th week production, (G) the 8th week production, (H) the 12th week production, (I) the 16th week production,(J) the 20th week production, (K) the 24th week production, (Pre) before production, (30 Dec) the early of 1st month production, (14 Jan) the middle of 1st month production, (29 Jan) the early of 2nd month production, (13 Feb) the middle of 2nd month production, (25 Feb) the early of 3rd month production, (7) a positive control.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The history of MJ-122 well production performance is shown in Figure 25. In this well, right after the microbial injection period the is water cut decreasing was started at the beginning of the production when the gross rate both decreased and raised. This was intended since we suspected the gross liquid rate should not be that high in order to maintain high numbers of microbes in the reservoirs. Then, after reaching a certain low value of gross liquid production, it was targeted to uprating gross liquid rate up to the original value. However, due to dropped pump efficiency, the gross rate could reach the initial level. Surprisingly, the oil rate was still increased until about 30% even though the gross rate remains the same.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Profile of MJ-122 well production performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profile of MJ-122 well production performance

linkTarget.anchoringText: The history of MJ-125 well production performance is shown in Figure 26. It can be obtained that there is an increasing oil rate from 51 BOPD in the beginning to 61 BOPD. This was also supported by the decreasing of 10% of water cut value before implementation of MEOR. This could be meant that water cut did not increase during the increase of gross flow rate, indicates that MEOR performance was successful on this well. This clearly shows that the MJ 125 has a better performance than the MJ-122. We will analyze further in the following.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Profile of MJ-125 well production performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profile of MJ-125 well production performance

linkTarget.anchoringText: The profile comparison of water cut and cumulative gross production on MJ-125 well before (blue) and after (red) microbial injection until March 2016 is illustrated in Figure 34. In this diagram, it can be seen that there is a shifting of water cut trend vs. gross of MJ-125 well which initially were located in quadrant IV to quadrant II and III. This condition proves that the water cut drop of MJ-125 well occurred both in a low and high production rate. This figure is the other way to clearly shows a comparison performance between the MJ-122 and MJ-125, and so the MJ-125 superiority.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Therefore, simulation was made by using a conventional simulator by using Eclipse ©. Figure 41 illustrate the location of the two wells that will be simulated. MJ-125 well is located at the center, while the MJ-122 well is on the edge of the reservoir model. Principle that used in reservoir simulation is to perform fluid flow matching produced by the fluid PVT data adjustment based on the changes of viscosity data which were obtained in the laboratory. The viscosity data were changed based on the time of MEOR implementation as an adjustment of the changes of fluid characteristics in the reservoir. Thus, the simulation results are able to demonstrate the increasing performance based on these implementations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 41
image-wrap.caption: A reservoir model with the location of MJ-122 and MJ-125 wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: A reservoir model with the location of MJ-122 and MJ-125 wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 42 is the simulation results before the adjustment of fluid viscosity was conducted.

image-wrap.label: Figure 42
image-wrap.caption: Liquid Production Rate of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid Production Rate of MJ-122

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 43 indicates a matching fluid rate based on the production data until 9 March 2016 as the matching reference. It can be seen that the reservoir model was still able to make production with constrain liquid rate suitable with the production history.

image-wrap.label: Figure 43
image-wrap.caption: Oil Rate Diagram of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil Rate Diagram of MJ-122

image-wrap.label: Figure 44
image-wrap.caption: Diagram Water Rate of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram Water Rate of MJ-122

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation of oil production rate necessarily needs to be increased, while the water production needs to be decreased. Therefore, there has to be done an adjustment to the data simulation by adjusting it into a circumstance after the MEOR implementation. The changed parameter is the oil viscosity based on the decrease of the data in the laboratory, the saturated oil residue (Sor) value resulted from biosurfactant forming mechanism and water viscosity. The increase of water viscosity was performed by enhancing the viscosity value of 4.5 times higher than before, so it reached 1.25 cP. Sor value was lowered by 10% from 0,23 into 0,203. Meanwhile, the viscosity of the oil was reduced by 50%, illustrated in Figure 45.

image-wrap.label: Figure 45
image-wrap.caption: The viscosity graph of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: The viscosity graph of MJ-122

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation result after a parameter adjustment was performed and illustrated in Figure 46 and Figure 47.

image-wrap.label: Figure 46
image-wrap.caption: Matching Diagram of Oil Production Rate of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: Matching Diagram of Oil Production Rate of MJ-122

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation result after a parameter adjustment was performed and illustrated in Figure 46 and Figure 47.

image-wrap.label: Figure 47
image-wrap.caption: Matching Diagram of Water Production Rate of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: Matching Diagram of Water Production Rate of MJ-122

image-wrap.label: Figure 48
image-wrap.caption: Diagram Forecast of MJ-122

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram Forecast of MJ-122

linkTarget.anchoringText: After the historical data matched with the simulation, it can be later continued to the performance production of MJ-122 well. The prediction process will last for 20 years starting from the last production data (9 March 2016), so that the simulation will be carried out until 1 January 2036, as illustrated at Figure 49.

image-wrap.label: Figure 49
image-wrap.caption: Liquid Production Rate of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Liquid Production Rate of MJ-125

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 50 resulted a matching of fluid rate based on the production data until 9 March 2016, the reservoir model is still capable of handling production with the constrain liquid rate with production history.

image-wrap.label: Figure 50
image-wrap.caption: Diagram Oil Rate of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram Oil Rate of MJ-125

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on Figure 50 and Figure 51, the simulation result is still not match with the trend of production until March 9, 2016. Therefore, a parameter adjustment from the software is necessarily needed to adapt. There is a shut-in period in the early production because of the early simulation period of both wells are the same while in its implementation, MJ-125 well begins producing after MJ-122 well is produced simultaneously. It can be resulted that MEOR implementation enhances the production rate observed from the simulation result.

image-wrap.label: Figure 51
image-wrap.caption: Diagram Water Rate of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram Water Rate of MJ-125

linkTarget.anchoringText: To adjust the simulation result with the data of well production, a parameter adjustment of oil viscosity was carried out. In this well, the adjustment was done by lowering the oil viscosity by 20%. In addition, the Sor value was also reduced by 10% due to the production of biosurfactant. The oil viscosity grade can be seen in the Figure 52.

image-wrap.label: Figure 52
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity Graphic of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity Graphic of MJ-125

linkTarget.anchoringText: The simulation result after the parameter adjustment was carried out is described in Figure 53.

image-wrap.label: Figure 53
image-wrap.caption: Match diagram of oil production rate of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Match diagram of oil production rate of MJ-125

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 54 shows the simulation results after a parameter adjustment of viscosity. It can be observed that the rate of oil and water are in accordance with production data. Therefore, it can be said that the laboratory results are matched with the simulation, no need for other adjustment but oil viscosity to be able to adjust the simulation results with field production data. Because the simulation has matched, it can later be conducted a prediction of well performances.

image-wrap.label: Figure 54
image-wrap.caption: Match diagram of water production rate of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Match diagram of water production rate of MJ-125

image-wrap.label: Figure 55
image-wrap.caption: Diagram forecast of MJ-125

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diagram forecast of MJ-125

image-wrap.label: Figure 56
image-wrap.caption: The location and the names of five-spot well

formatted-caption.caption-text: The location and the names of five-spot well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on that trend, it can say that the 1-month-decrease takes up to 75%, for 2-month-decrease reaches 55%, and for 3-month-decrease is as much as 40%. Restrictions were also performed on the injection well and production well from the pattern. The production well used flow rate limit of each well as many as 400 BFPD, and for the entire field was 800 BFPD. In addition, the restrictions of the injection wells were given rate of 500 BWPD. The prediction was done by making three cases of injection models comparatively varied with their types of length of microbial injection. Every planned case can be studied in this figure below Figure 57.

image-wrap.label: Figure 57
image-wrap.caption: The definition of each simulation case

formatted-caption.caption-text: The definition of each simulation case

image-wrap.label: Figure 58
image-wrap.caption: The increase of oil production rate after the MEOR implementation

formatted-caption.caption-text: The increase of oil production rate after the MEOR implementation

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 59 resulted that the greatest increase appeared in Case 1 where MEOR injection was directly conducted in 3 months and was continued by water flood process. The overall increase of oil production results can be examined in the Table 16 and Table 17.

image-wrap.label: Figure 59
image-wrap.caption: The cumulative increase of oil production after the MEOR implementation MEOR

formatted-caption.caption-text: The cumulative increase of oil production after the MEOR implementation MEOR
